metadata.title: Microwave processed bulk and nano NiMg ferrites: A comparative study on X-band electromagnetic interference shielding properties

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Materials Chemistry and Physics
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/matchemphys
Microwave processed bulk and nano NiMg ferrites: A comparative study on X-band electromagnetic interference shielding properties
K. Chandra Babu Naidu a, W. Madhuri a, b, *
a Ceramic Composite Laboratory, Centre for Crystal Growth, SAS, VIT University, Vellore 632014, Tamilnadu, India b IFW, Leibniz Institute for Solid State and Materials Research, Technische Universit€at Dresden, 01069 Dresden, Germany
h i g h l i g h t s
* Corresponding author. Ceramic Composite Lab Growth, SAS, VIT University, Vellore 632014, Tamilna
E-mail addresses: chandrababu954@gmail.com madhuriw12@gmail.com (W. Madhuri).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.matchemphys.2016.11.062 0254-0584/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Bulk and nano NiMg ferrites are prepared by microwave and hydrothermal method.
X-band EMI shielding properties are studied for both bulk and nano ferrites.
Bulk Ni0.6Mg0.4Fe2O4 revealed the highest SET of ~17 dB at 8.4 GHz. Bulk x ¼ 0.4 & 0.6 showed the high ε00 and m00 at 12 GHz for absorber applications.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 September 2016 Received in revised form 2 November 2016 Accepted 29 November 2016 Available online 30 November 2016
Keywords: Ferrites Microwaves Hydrothermal technique Electromagnetic properties Microwave absorbers
a b s t r a c t
Bulk and nano Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) samples were synthesized via microwave double sintering and microwave assisted hydrothermal techniques respectively. The diffraction pattern confirmed the formation of cubic spinel phases in case of both the ferrites. The larger bulk densities were achieved to the bulk than that of nano. In addition, a comparative study on X-band (8.4e12 GHz) electromagnetic interference shielding properties of current bulk and nanomaterials was elucidated. The results showed that the bulk Ni0.6Mg0.4Fe2O4 composition revealed the highest total shielding efficiency (SET) of ~17 dB. In comparison, the shielding efficiency values of all bulk contents were higher than that of nano because of larger bulk densities. Moreover, the ac-electromagnetic parameters such as electrical conductivity (sac), the respective real (ε0 & m0) and imaginary parts (ε00 & m00) of complex permittivity and permeability were investigated as a function of gigahertz frequency. The bulk ferrites of x ¼ 0.4 & 0.6 showed the high ε 00 of 10.26 & 6.71 and m00 of 3.65 & 3.09 respectively at 12 GHz which can work as promising microwave absorber materials. Interestingly, nanoferrites exhibited negative m00 values at few frequencies due to geometrical effects which improves the microwave absorption.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
oratory, Centre for Crystal du, India. (K. Chandra Babu Naidu),

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In a true sense, the electromagnetic interference (EMI) has emerged as a significant problem to the communication and sensitive device fabrication industries. Since the current technology in communication system runs on the wireless network with high speed [1]. Therefore, an effective shielding method is required in
order to shield the EM radiation. In view of this, various shielding mechanisms such as reflection (SER), absorption (SEA) and multiple reflections (SEM) have been incorporated in order to shield the EM wave [2,3]. The shielding effectiveness of materials basically depends on the excellence of dielectric properties [3]. Usually, metals perform extremely good dielectric and conductivity properties offering the effective shielding properties. However, metals show few difficulties such as expensive, high weight, high density and poor mechanical stability [4]. As reported in the literature [5,6], the acconductivity (s) and relative permeability (mr) dependence of EMI shielding by reflection (SER) and absorption (SEA) are governed by the following relations:
SER ¼ 39:6þ 10 log s
umr (1)
SEA ¼ 12:3t ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiusmr p
(2)
where u ¼ 2pf, ‘f’ is the applied frequency and ‘t’ is the thickness of shield. From the above mentioned relations, it is evident that the SER is directly proportional to the ac-electrical conductivity of the shielding material while it is inversely proportional to the relative permeability of the material. On the other hand, the SEA is directly proportional to both s and mr of the sample. The third mechanism (SEM) reveals the internal reflections within the shield. However, the SEM can be neglected as it cannot be quantified as a separate factor [7]. Using the higher SET values of the specimen, the better attenuation of EMwave can be achieved. It is normally measured in terms of decibels (dB). Several researchers have reported that the approximate SET value of order 10e20 dB is most abundant for real time applications such as shielding for laptop and desktop systems. Moreover, the cell phones need EMI SET value of order 70e90 dB [8].
Ferrites are the promising candidate magnetic materials used for distinct industrial applications such as microwave, telecommunication, data storage, inductor-core and electromagnetic devices [9]. Indeed, different ferrites and hexaferrite composites have been investigated for microwave absorption applications. Mn-Zn, NiZn, NiZnCo ferrites, BaZnCo U-hexaferrites and hexaferrite composites are a few to mention [10e14] for microwave absorber materials. These materials performed a wide range of applications in various fields such as defense and telecommunications [15]. Absorbers can work as potential attenuators for electromagnetic waves (EMW). For example, radar absorbers have been used for aircraft and commercial television image interference. The stray radiation and reflection can be minimized via absorber set up at particular objects. Thus, the environment becomes free of microwaves minimizing the extinction of some creatures on earth. However, the absorber material is a dependent of complex permittivity (ε*) and permeability (m*). These are given by equations: ε* ¼ ε0-j ε00 and m* ¼ m0-j m00, where real parts of ε* and m* are known as dielectric constant and magnetic permeability of materials while imaginary parts are regarded as dielectric and magnetic losses respectively. The parameters of ε0 and m0 measure the effect of materials on electric and magnetic components of the electromagnetic wave. On the other hand, ε00 and m00 provide the attenuation (loss) of electric and magnetic fields caused by the ferrite specimen. In order to obtain better absorbing properties ε0, m0, ε00 and m00 should be as high as possible. Therefore, the lossy ferrites canwork as effective microwave absorbers and poor dielectric [15]. Microwave absorber materials have to show very low conductivity so as to avoid often direct contact with circuit elements (capacitors, inductors and connecting wires etc.).
Nanoferrites have also been the promising materials for
microwave device, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), catalysis, magnetic recording, microwave absorber, biosensors, biomedical drug delivery, power transformers and telecommunication applications due to their high thermal stability, enhanced electrical, optical and magnetic properties when compared with bulk materials [15e19]. Ferrites and hexa ferrites in nano form can also provide applications for the suppression of EM radiation. Recently, several scientists have reported the shielding properties of nano NiCoZnLaFe2O4, BaFe12O19 and NiZnLaFe2O4 etc. [20e22]. Haung et al. [23e26] investigated the electromagnetic properties of light weight zinc ferrite nanofibers, iron oxide nanofibers, cobalt-zinc ferrites and porous BaFe12O19/CoFe2O4 composite. The results showed that the zinc ferrite nanofibers showed an improvement of dielectric andmagnetic loss which in turn enhances the microwave absorption property [23]. The as prepared iron oxide nanofibers showed the excellent electromagnetic loss properties although the samples are light weight [24]. The effect of pH on electromagnetic properties was also studied. As the pH value decreased from 11 to 9, the dielectric and magnetic loss were dramatically increased to larger value [25]. The low weight porous BaFe12O19/CoFe2O4 composite microrods were used to solve effectively the heavy mass problem of conventional hard/soft ferrite matrix microwave absorption material [26]. In the recent published work, low frequency (<10 MHz) electrical and permeability properties of bulk and nano NiMg ferrites have been investigated using different techniques such as citrate-gel [27,28], self-combustion sol-gel [29], egg-white precursor [30], chemical co-precipitation [31,32], self-combustion sol-gel [33] and microwave sintering techniques [34]. In this study, the authors have adopted two techniques viz., microwave double sintering and microwave assisted hydrothermal techniques to synthesize bulk and nanoferrites respectively. Microwave sintering is a rapid heating technique and its significance on structural and magnetic properties of the present bulk NiMg ferrite compositions was clearly discussed by the authors in the previous reports [35]. In addition, the hydrothermal method offers many advantages over the rest of methods such as the low cost for sample preparation, high crystallinity, simplicity and usage of low temperatures. To the best of author's knowledge bulk as well as nano NiMg ferrite samples have not yet studied for EMI shielding properties. Hence, in this investigation, an attempt has been made to report the comparative X-band (8.4e12 GHz) EMI shielding properties of bulk and nano Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) prepared by microwave double sintering and microwave assisted hydrothermal techniques for probable EMI shielding applications.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental procedure
sections.text:
The experimental part of bulk Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) was discussed in the author's previous work [34]. The X-band pellets of dimensions of length ~2.286 cm and breadth 1.016 cm were prepared using a die set. The photograph of pellets placed on a graph sheet was shown in Fig. 1. These bulk pellets (ferrites) were kept in a microwave furnace (Fig. 2) and were sintered at 1000 C/30 min.
The photograph of microwave furnace (V.B. Ceramics, India) was shown in Fig. 2. It consists of two magnetrons with an oscillating frequency of 2.45 GHz generating an output power of 2.2 kW. The temperature sensor was used to sense the temperature maintained in the sample holder. The silicon carbide plates were arranged inside the sample holder in order to maintain heat for a long time. In this technique, the ceramic samples can be heated directly. The microwave frequency develops the temperature within a ceramic material. It can be achieved to the passage of high frequency oscillations of 2.45 GHz from two magnetron sources within the sample volume. Hence, the dipoles also can oscillate with the same frequency generating more uniform heat among the dipoles. This
can constitute rapid heating within the sample avoiding the heat wastage.
In order to synthesize Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) nano-particles Ni (NO3)2 6H2O, Fe (NO3)3 9H2O, Mg (NO3)2 6H2O (each of 99.8% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) and NaOH were chosen as precursors. The nitrate compounds were dissolved in deionized water taken in the ratio of nitrates (gm): water (ml) as 1:3. The resultant solution was stirred until it gets dissolved in D2O. NaOH (gm) was added in a small portion to the solution (ml) in 1:4 (NaOH: nitrates) ratio until the pH¼ 11 was obtained. Furthermore, the mixture was vigorously stirred for 2 h and transferred into a 300 ml Teflon-lined steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heat treated at 150 C for 48 h. After 48 h, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature. The surface water was removed and the solution was washed with acetone and distilled water for number of times till PH was decreased to 7. Later the nano-particles were separated from the autoclave and dried at 60 C for 6 h. The schematic diagram of the experimental procedure for NiMg ferrites was shown in Fig. 3. The similar procedure was followed for each time so as to prepare all nano ferrite compositions. The as prepared X-band pellets of nanoferrites (as shown in Fig. 4 on a graph sheet) were treated with microwaves at a temperature of 500 C for 10 min. The heated samples were characterized using the X-ray diffractometer (Bruker X-Ray Powder Diffractometer, CuKa, l ¼ 0.15418 nm) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM: Model Tecnai G20, FEI, USA) for structural and morphological studies. Moreover, the X-band EMI
shielding efficiency of the sintered samples was obtained from the scattering parameters measured by transmission-reflection technique using a vector network analyzer (Agilent N5230C) (Fig. 5). While doing measurement the X-band pellet was inserted in a sample holder as shown in Fig. 5. The respective real (ε0 & m0) and imaginary parts (ε00 & m00) of complex permittivity and permeability of the samples were obtained by using the materials measurement software (85071D) under the same configuration of samples used to obtain scattering parameters.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structural analysis
sections.text:
The diffraction pattern and analysis of bulk Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) was shown in the author's published work [34]. The assynthesized ferrites (hydrothermal reaction at 150 C for 48 h) other than x ¼ 0 reveal the presence of secondary phases in the diffraction pattern. Hence, the samples are microwave heat treated at a temperature of 500 C for 10 min. This heating temperature is chosen based on the literature survey. According to the literature survey, Xia et al. [36], experimentally observed the presence of secondary phases in the diffraction pattern of hydrothermal synthesized MgZnFe2O4 nano-particles at 200 C. The reports also suggested that the Mg-addition in ZnFe2O4 needs higher temperatures around 460 C. This evidently reveals a fact that the present
hydrothermal synthesized samples (at 150 C for 48 h) need higher temperatures for pure phase formation. Sasaki et al. [37], prepared pure MgFe2O4 (MF) at 460 C via hydrothermal reaction. From the overall literature survey, it is expected that Mg-addition in NiFe2O4 also needs heat treatment around 500 C in order to obtain pure phases. Fig. 6 shows the variation of intensity as a function of two theta angle (2q) from 10 to 80 of nano NiMg ferrite system. All ferrites exhibit perfect single phase cubic structure as expected and are inconsistent with standard JCPDS files: 86e2267 & 71e1232. The NiFe2O4 shows high crystallinity while the remaining ferrites exhibit moderate crystallinity. The average crystallite size ‘D’ is calculated from full-width half maxima (FWHM) of all intense cubic phases using the Scherrer equation: D¼ 0.9l/bCosq, where ‘l’ is the wavelength of X-ray radiation, ‘q’ is the diffraction angle and ‘b’ is FWHM [38]. The results are listed in Table 1. It can be understood from the table that x¼ 0 to 0.8 show ‘D’ values are varying between 7.4 and 13.0 nm. But for MgFe2O4, it is found to be of order 42 nm which is smaller than the reported value of 370 nm by solvothermal technique at an ambient temperature of 200 C/22 h [39]. This reveals a fact that microwave treatment of hydrothermal synthesized MF results in smaller crystallite sizes. The lattice constants (a, b & c) are evaluated from inter-planar spacing and miller indices (hkl) (see Table 1). The achieved value of ‘a’ for x ¼ 0 is 0.833 nm
which is almost equal to the reported data [31]. The lattice constants are increasing with increase in x (from 0 to 1) from 0.833 to 0.848 nm. Since the ionic radius of Mg2þ (0.072 nm) is greater than that of Ni2þ (0.069 nm) and Fe3þ (0.064 nm) [40]. These bigger ions try to occupy the sites of smaller ions and as a result, the unit cell dimensions (lattice constants) are increased in the resultant spinel structure. Similar kind of observation is noticed in bulk NiMg ferrites [34]. X-ray density is calculated for all contents using a relation: rx ¼ ZM/Na3, where ‘Z’ is the number of molecules per unit cell (Z ¼ 8), ‘M’ is the molecular weight of the composition, ‘N’ is Avogadro's number (6.023 1023) and ‘a’ is the lattice parameter [34]. The calculated values are observed to be increasing with Mg2þ ions from 5.392 to 4.498 g/cm3. The bulk densities (rb) are evaluated using the ratio of mass (m) and volume (V~0.25.p2 (R þ r) (R r)2) of the toroidal specimen, where R & r are the outer and inner radii of toroid in inches. These densities are decreasing from x¼ 0 to 1 except for x¼ 0.5. The low concentration of defect centers may be the reason for the increase in bulk density at x ¼ 0.5. Further, the porosity (P~1-(rb/rx), where the symbols have their usual meaning) is calculated and the results are reported in Table 1.
The results show that the porosity is decreasing with x up to x¼ 0.5 and beyond it is increasing. The high bulk density may lead to low porosity at x ¼ 0.5. Few structural parameters such as dislocation density (rd) which provides the defects per unit area, unit cell volume (V) and BET specific surface area (S) are calculated and shown in Table 1. Normally, the specific surface area (S) is one of the physical properties of nanomaterials. It distinguishes the bulk and nanomaterials based on crystallite size. The highest ‘S’ values are achieved for all compositions other than x ¼ 0.5 & 1. This may be attributed to the larger crystallite size [35].

sections.heading: 3.2. TEM analysis
sections.text:
The microstructure of bulk ferrites was shown and discussed in the author's reported work [3034]. The surface morphology of microwave heated ferrites at 500 C is analyzed by transmission electron microscope (TEM). Fig. 7 shows the TEM images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of microwave heated nano NiMg ferrites. The average particle size is altering between 20.1 and 81.8 nm. The obtained NiFe2O4 particle size is much smaller than the reported value of 170 nm byWang et al. [41], via solvothermal technique (at 180 C/48 h). This kind of smaller particle size is attributed to lowering the operating temperature in hydrothermal method (150 C/48 h). Nevertheless, the hydrothermal product is undergonemicrowave heat treatment at 500 C for a shorter soaking time of 10 min. All TEM images show wellagglomerated plate like particles. The magnetic interactions between nano-particles are responsible for the agglomeration [42]. The SAED pattern displays the good crystalline nature of single phase nanoferrites (Fig.12). It is indexed by (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) planes which are in agreement with the reflection planes in X-ray diffraction pattern. The diffused like diffraction pattern is noticed for MgFe2O4 with weak crystallinity.
3.3. EMI shielding parameters of bulk Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1)
Fig. 8 (a) depicts the EMI shielding efficiency of Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) samples in the frequency range of 8.4e12 GHz (X-band). It is seen from figure that x¼ 0.4, 0.5& 0.6 compositions exhibit the maximum SET values of 17 dB, 14.3 dB and 12.3 dB respectively at 8.4 GHz. The rest compositions attribute the SET in the range of ~10e11 dB (at 8.4 GHz). As the frequency increases from 8.4 to 12 GHz, the SET is independent of the frequency for x ¼ 0.4 & 0.5. On the other hand, the SET for x ¼ 0, 0.2, 0.8 & 1 is decreasing with increase in frequency. But interestingly, x¼ 0.6 shows an increasing trend with the frequency which can be happened mainly owing to the increase in electrical conductivity from 3.74 10 2 S/cm (at 8.4 GHz) to 7.11 10 2 S/cm (at 12 GHz). It is awell-known fact that EMI shielding efficiency is dependent on electrical conductivity (sac~εoε002pf). The directly proportional dependence of sac with SET is experimentally reported in the literature [43]. In order to establish better shielding property, the shield must possess electric/magnetic dipoles which are to be activated easily by the input signal. Subsequently, the carriers are easily polarized which in turn offer high dielectric constant. Hence, it enhances sac thereby increasing the dielectric loss (ε00). The corresponding sac values of x¼ 0e1 are reported in Table 2. The sac dependence as a function of X-band frequency is shown in Fig. 8 (b). It is observed from figure that x ¼ 0.4 & 0.5 show almost a constant variation trend while x ¼ 0.6 performs an increasing trend with frequency. The rest of compositions show a decreasing trend of sac over 8.4e12 GHz frequency range. These results reflect in EMI shielding ability of ferrites. However, x ¼ 0.4, 0.5 & 0.6 samples show the better EMI shielding efficiency than x ¼ 0, 0.2, 0.8 & 1.
The composition dependence of SER, SEA & SET is shown in
Table 2. It is clear from data present in table that x ¼ 0.4, 0.5 & 0.6 contents show the better improvement of SEA values to 12.1 dB, 7.7 dB & 12.1 dB (at 12 GHz) than values at 8.4 GHz (Table 2). These compositions only provide the highest EMI shielding efficiency. Furthermore, it is noticed that the absorption mechanism shows more contribution in achieving the maximum shielding efficiency than reflection mechanism. Based on the obtained results, it is concluded that the EMISET is strongly dominated by absorption mechanism in case of bulk ferrites. The electron motion among the dipoles induces the polarization process under the acelectromagnetic field which enhances the microwave absorption attenuation [44].
3.4. X-band electromagnetic parameters of bulk Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1)
Dielectric constant (ε0) and dielectric loss (ε00) values at two frequencies (lower & higher frequencies) are reported in Table 2.
The frequency dependence of ε0 and ε00 is illustrated in Fig. 9 (a) & (b) respectively. It is evident from figures that these parameters are decreasing with frequency revealing the frequency dependent dielectric response (except for x ¼ 0.6). This occurs due to decreasing the ability of the dipoles to maintain in phase moment with rapidly pulsating electric vector of EM wave [44]. The high dielectric constant values are achieved for x ¼ 0.4, 0.5 & 0.6 (Table 2). These higher values lead to high dielectric losses which in turn support to improve the EMI shielding efficiency. This dielectric loss can also be attributed to the interfacial polarization. Among all the compositions, x ¼ 0.6 shows very interesting behavior among all dielectric properties. As the frequency goes on increasing, it exhibits an increasing trend of ε0 and ε00 values instead of a usual behavior. It can be attributed to the noticeable enhancement of polarization (dielectric constant) of respective NiMg ferrite compositions. However, this kind of ability is more suitable in order to fabricate promising X-band microwave shields.
The complex permeability (m*) of bulk ferrites is also studied during 8.4e12 GHz frequency range. Normally, m0 is associated with the magnetic energy storage which arises from the alignment of magnetic dipoles in the direction of input magnetic field whereas m00 is assigned to the magnetic loss ability which can be influenced by few experiences such as eddy current loss, ferromagnetic resonance, magnetic hysteresis loop and domain wall displacement [45]. The variation of initial permeability (m0) andmagnetic loss (m00) as a function of composition and frequency is shown in Fig. 10. It is obvious from m0 versus frequency plots that m0 is slowly decreasing with frequency up to 9.5 GHz for x¼ 0& 0.6 expressing an inversely proportional relationship. But interestingly, m0 of remaining compositions show an increasing trend with frequency up to 8.9 GHz including few small relaxations. These peaks may be related to natural resonance and eddy current loss phenomenon [45]. It can also be seen from Fig. 10 that on reaching higher frequencies, x ¼ 0e1 contents perform strong resonance or relaxation peaks around 10 GHz. The inset figure of m0-f plot attributes a small right shift in resonance frequency (fr) from 10.01 to 10.08 GHz for x ¼ 0e0.8 compositions respectively where as MgFe2O4 (x ¼ 1) shows fr ~9.99 GHz. It may be attributed to the high non-magnetic Mg-content. Moreover, several factors like eddy current loss and natural resonance phenomenon may lead to low resonance frequency [45]. Normally, this behavior is evolved among the magnetic dipoles where exactly the applied field frequency becomes almost equal to the precision frequency of spinning electrons. At this juncture, a part of the magnetic energy is propagated from the input field to the moving dipoles with a certain frequency. As a result, the magnetic dipoles perform high orientation with greater velocity offering to the enhancement of domainwall velocity. Thus, m0 attainsmaximumvalue at resonance peak. For further increase of frequency greater than 10.08 GHz, it starts decreasing to smaller values obeying Snoek's law [46]. Furthermore, the compositions x ¼ 0.4 & 0.5 show gradual increasing trend while x ¼ 0.6 performs a drastic increasing trend with increase in frequency. This kind of interesting behavior may be attributed to the enhanced response of magnetic dipoles with frequency. On the other hand, the rest of contents exhibit almost a constant trend with the frequency indicating the constant response of dipoles. The lagging of domain wall motionwith input ac-fields attempts to generate magnetic loss (m00) [47]. Moreover, this magnetic loss can also be caused by exchange resonance. The m00 versus frequency plot of x¼ 0e1 also displays the similar trend as that of m0 during the X-band frequency range. According to the observations, the small dispersion peaks at lower frequencies (>9 GHz) are due to domain wall moment while the spin rotation contributes to the formation of sharp dispersion peaks around 10 GHz. A similar trend is reported in the literature [48]. However, m00 values of x ¼ 0, 0.2, 0.8 & 1 are almost zero at 12 GHz

indicating very less magnetic loss for incident EMwave. The results are reported in Table 2. It is noticed that x ¼ 0.4e0.6 contents acquire the maximum m00 of 3.7, 1.2 & 3.1 respectively at 12 GHz. Hence, these lossy ferrites are used as microwave absorber materials [48].
3.5. X-band EMI shielding parameters of nano Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1)
Fig. 11 (a) shows the variation of EMI SET of nano NiMg ferrite system as a function of X-band frequency. It is observed from the figure that the compositions x ¼ 0.5e0.8 show a constant trend of total shielding efficiency during 8.4e12 GHz frequency. This reveals a fact that the SET value of these compositions is independent of the X-band frequency. In contrast, this variation trend is comparable with sac (Fig. 11 (b)) versus frequency behavior of similar compositions and maintains the directly proportional relation between SET and sac. The similar behavior is reported in the literature [49]. On the other hand, x ¼ 0e0.4 & 1 contents perform a gradual decreasing trend of SET value establishing the frequency dependent property. The associated results of all shielding parameters at 8.4 GHz and 12 GHz are tabulated in Table 3. For x ¼ 0e1, the reflection shielding efficiency is varying from ~3.4 to 5.6 dB at 8.4 GHz while it is of order ~1.3e3.5 dB at 12 GHz. The absorption shielding efficiency is about ~1e3 dB at 8.4 GHz while it shows ~1.2e2.9 dB for x ¼ 0e1. The measured data of SEA is more or less a steady value for the entire frequency range. The composition dependence of SET parameter expresses that it is altering between ~4.5e8.6 dB at 8.4 GHz while it ranges from ~3.5e6.4 dB at 12 GHz. The SET value starts increasing with ‘x’ up to 50% of Mg-addition and beyond it is almost a steady value of ~6 dB. This occurs due to conductivity variation with ‘x’. Since it also decreases from 8.6 10 3 to 2.6 10 3 S/cm with the dopant and further it maintains almost a constant trend with a numerical value of approximately 0.01 S/cm. The overall analysis on shielding parameters of nanoferrites establishes a fact that the major contribution of SET arises from reflectionmechanismwhere as absorption mechanism contributes a little in order to shield the EM radiation.
3.6. X-band electromagnetic parameters of nano Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1)
In order to study the EMI shielding properties of nano NiMg
ferrites the electromagnetic parameters such as complex permittivity (ε*) and permeability (m*) are extracted from the S-parameters (S11 & S21) with the help of Nicholson-Ross-Weir method [50e52]. Fig. 12 (a) & (b) show the frequency dependence of ε0 and ε 00 as a function of various Mg-compositions in nano NiFe2O4. It is seen from figures that ε0 as well as ε00 of x ¼ 0e1, performs almost a constant trend throughout X-band frequency. But x ¼ 0 & 0.2 contentsmanifest the dielectric relaxations which can be attributed to the consequences of distinct polar groups trying to follow the input field [53]. However, the existence of conductive species constitutes the polarization by offering the quick response to the applied field frequency. As a result, beyond relaxation frequency, ε0 and ε00 start to increase again. In the loss plot of x ¼ 0, at 11.7 GHz a sharp relaxation or resonance peak is obtained. This kind of behavior is usually appeared in heterogeneous media owing to the accumulation of electrons and holes at the grain boundary interface [54]. Moreover, the increase of conductivity and dipole moment is also a significant reason for the sharp resonance peak in ε00 plot. In the current study, it is practically noticed at 11.7 GHz for both loss and ac-conductivity plots. Similar kind of observation is reported in the literature [55]. The composition dependence of ε0 and ε00 of nanoferrites at 8.4 GHz and 12 GHz frequencies is shown in Table 3. It is clear that ε0 and ε00 values are altering between 5.1e9.3 and 0.6e2.7 respectively. The high ε0 and ε00 values are achieved for x¼ 0 & 0.6 at 8.4 GHz. This allows to have higher conductivity of ~0.09 S/ cm & 0.01 S/cm for x ¼ 0 & 0.6 compositions respectively at 8.4 GHz. The higher numerical values of ε0 and ε00 prevails a significant contribution in achieving high total shielding efficiency thereby increasing the conductivity. Since for the gigahertz input field frequency, if the dipoles of material content respond quickly, these dipoles must oscillate with almost same frequency. During these oscillations, some amount of heat is generated which contributes to the ac-conductivity.
Therefore, the high SET is established for x ¼ 0 & 0.6 contents acquiring shielding applications in laptops and desktop computers [8].
Besides, the complex permeability (m*) of nanoferrites over Xband frequency range is also investigated. Fig. 13 shows the X-band frequency dependence of permeability (m0) and magnetic loss (m00) [56] as a function of Mg-content. It is evident from the figure that initial permeability is almost a constant value during 8.4e12 GHz frequency range. The resultant values at 8.4 GHz and 12 GHz of all the ferrites are listed in Table 3. At 8.4 GHz, m0 marginally increases
from ~1.0e1.27 for x¼ 0e0.6. Beyond x¼ 0.6, it is slowly decreasing to ~1.1. It shows a steady value of ~1 at 12 GHz. Thus, it varies around ~1. The resonance behavior is noticed at ~9.8 GHz. At this frequency, m0 obeys the Snoek's law of permeability as described in bulk NiMgZn ferrites [57]. This kind of smaller value of permeability establishes a fact that the present nanoferrites are of non-magnetic in nature [56]. The m00 also exhibits a constant variation with an increase in applied frequency. However, m00 values of all compositions are almost zero demonstrating the very less magnetic loss for an incident electromagnetic wave. But, interestingly, the m00 plot of ferrites gradually decreases and becomes negative above 11 GHz. It is cleared from the data listed in Table 3. This kind of behavior is reported in the literature [56,58]. There are various reasons in the literature for the occurrence of negative m00 value. Markel [59], proposed that m00 remains negative in X-band frequency due to the porous diamagnetic property of material. But in this study, the ferrite contents are not showing diamagnetic property in M H
loop [34]. Therefore, this reason cannot be applicable to the present nanoferrites. Fletcher et al. [58], reported that few geometrical effects may lead to negative m00 value and it can improve the microwave absorption. However, the absolute eve value of m00 is very small. This also suggests that the interaction between current nanoferrites and incident electromagnetic wave can induce the change of magnetic field and little magnetic energies can be radiated out [56].

sections.heading: 3.7. Comparison of X-band EMI shielding parameters between bulk and nano NiMg ferrites
sections.text:
In general, the SET of a material is directly proportional to the associated ac-electrical conductivity of that particular material. However, the ac-electrical conductivity is a dependent of bulk density, porosity, dislocation density and particle sizes of samples [35]. In this study, the dependence of the above-mentioned
properties is clearly observed. The bulk density of bulk NiMg ferrites is altering between ~4.465 and 5.364 g/cm3 where as for nanoferrites, it ranges from ~3.152e4.331 g/cm3. This explicitly indicates that the numerical values of bulk densities of bulk ferrites are higher than that of nanoferrites. Therefore, the bulk ferrites unveil almost 50% greater SET in value (~10e17 dB at 8.4 GHz) than that of nanoferrites (~4.5e8.6 dB at 8.4 GHz). Moreover, the acconductivity of bulk ferrites is of order 10 2 S/cm and for nano materials, it is approximately 10 3 S/cm. Hence, the higher conductivity value of bulk than nano reflects in achieving higher SET values. In addition, the larger particle sizes of bulk samples (~1.66e3.71 mm) [34] than that of nanomaterials (~20e82 nm) can also influence the SET value thereby affecting the ac-conductivity. Since the compositions pertaining bigger particles exhibit high conductivity than smaller grains as reported by Nikumbh et al., [60]. Usually, smaller sized grains in a particular area or volume of material content offer high dislocation density where as bigger sized particles provide low dislocation density. Thus, bulk materials reduce the scattering of electrons by increasing electrical conductivity. Consequently, it allows increasing the shielding efficiency. Besides, the porosity of bulk (~0.071e0.096) and nanoferrites (~0.104e0.299) is evaluated. This parameter is directly proportional to dislocation density as reported in the literature [57]. Therefore, the high porosity decreases the conductivity which in turn leads to the decrease of SET. On the other hand, the low porosity achieved for bulk ferrites manifests the high SET value. However, the overall analysis on shielding parameters of bulk and nano expresses a fact that the major contribution of SET is due to reflection mechanism in case of nano where as absorption mechanism offers a larger contribution to shield EM radiation in case of bulk.

sections.heading: 3.8. Comparison of X-band electromagnetic parameters between bulk and nano NiMg ferrites
sections.text:
The bulk NiMg ferrites show higher ε0, ε00 and sac values than nanoferrites. This can be attributed to the higher density, lower porosity and bigger diameter of grains of bulk ferrites when compared with nanoferrites as discussed earlier. In respect of permeability studies, the nanomaterials show smaller m00 values than bulk. This indicates that the nanoferrites have the very less magnetic loss for the incident electromagnetic wave. The m0 of bulk compositions such as x ¼ 0.4, 0.6 & 1 are marginally larger than nano while the rest compositions are almost equal to the m0 of nanomaterials. The m0 in ferrites normally arises from the spin rotation and domain wall motion of magnetic dipoles. In bulk
(x¼ 0.4, 0.6& 1) compositions, it seems higher than nano. The very interesting aspect between bulk and nanoferrites is the sign of m00. The bulk shows positive m00 while nanoferrites show eve m00. The reasons behind this are discussed earlier. However, the eve m00 can improve the microwave absorption.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The bulk and nano Ni1-xMgxFe2O4 (x ¼ 0e1) ferrites were prepared by microwave double sintering and microwave assisted hydrothermal methods respectively. The formation of cubic spinel phases was confirmed by diffraction pattern. The high electromagnetic interference shielding efficiency of 17 dB, 14.3 dB and 12.3 dB (at 8.4 GHz) was obtained for x ¼ 0.4, 0.5 & 0.6 compositions respectivelywhich canwork as EMI shieldingmaterials. It was also observed that x ¼ 0.4 to 0.6 compositions offer the highest m00 of 3.7, 1.2 & 3.1 respectively at 12 GHz. Thus, these lossy ferrites can be used as potential microwave absorber materials. Comparatively,
the bulk ferrites unveil almost 50% greater SET in value (~10e17 dB at 8.4 GHz) than that of nanoferrites (~4.5e8.6 dB at 8.4 GHz). This major difference was happened due to the density variations between bulk and nanoferrites. Moreover, the acconductivity of bulk ferrites is of order 10 2 S/cm and for nanomaterials, it is of order 10 3 S/cm. The major contribution of SET arises from reflection mechanism in case of nano where as absorption mechanism offers a larger contribution to shield the EM radiation in bulk. Interestingly, nanoferrites exhibit negative m00
values at few frequencies owing to geometrical effects which can enhance the microwave absorption.
